At that time, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, addressed the World-Honored One, saying:

In this way, World-Honored One!

These true heroes who practice the inconceivable Dharma with complete mastery, wherever they go, they will everywhere illuminate with the radiance of the Dharma treasure, and they will immediately cultivate and manifest the original limit, becoming capable of freely expounding eloquence. Those who are self-indulgent will have no attachment to any dharmas and will not be attached to self and others.

Those with eloquent eloquence subdue all arrogance and transform themselves into great envoys with no different decisions;
Those with eloquent eloquence enable all demons to find no opportunity, and when listening and reflecting, they transcend demonic affairs;

Those with eloquent eloquence cause all good dharmas that have not yet been encouraged to arise, and having arisen, they do not violate or forget them. If dust and afflictions arise, they cause them to be eliminated, and if dust and afflictions have not yet arisen, they cause them to be unable to arise.
Those with eloquent eloquence cause all bodhisattvas who have not yet donned the armor of virtue to be able to don it, and those who have donned it do not regress;
Those with eloquent eloquence do not cut off the true Dharma and protect the true canon.
By this analogy of eloquence, one is able to subdue all non-Buddhist teachings.
Why is it so?
It is because small animals can never endure the roar of a lion. Seeing a lion, they cannot advance on their own, let alone enter its cave or roam in the forest.

All non-Buddhists are unable to roar the supreme lion's roar.

The reason it is called the lion's roar is because if one can be single-minded and not conceive of a self or an 'I,' all dharmas are merely conventional expressions of worldly customs.
The reason it is called the lion's roar is because it uses singularity to proclaim the Dharma of emptiness;

The reason it is called the lion's roar is because it eliminates the suffering and afflictions of all beings, and when one attains Buddhahood, it proclaims this teaching;

Therefore, it is said that the lion's roar means dwelling in seclusion without choosing where to go.

The basis of giving, creating the foremost, is the lion's roar; not abandoning precepts is the lion's roar; treating friends and enemies equally is the lion's roar; not abandoning the distant and not having anything near is the lion's roar; eliminating all afflictions is the lion's roar; equally contemplating wisdom is the lion's roar.

When the celestial son spoke this lion's roar, the trichiliocosm shook six times, hundreds of thousands of musical instruments sounded without being played, and the great light universally illuminated the world and the celestial palaces.

Like clouds, mist, and lightning, empty like a mass of foam and an illusion,

The Buddha said to Brahma-king Mind-king:

The celestial son of Unremitting Progress will attain Buddhahood in thirty-two incalculable eons, and will be called Sumeru Lamp King Tathagata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One, Perfect in Knowledge and Conduct, Well-Gone, Knower of the Secular World, Unsurpassed Person, Tamer, Teacher of Gods and Men, Buddha, World-Honored One. His buddha land will have two treasures, namely dark blue lapis lazuli and purple gold. It will be filled with bodhisattvas and will subdue Mara's army. The dwellings, clothing, and food there will be like those in the sixth heaven of the desire realm.

He replied:

He replied:
Brahma Heaven!

He further asked:

He replied:
Not abiding in the two paths is to establish all Dharma teachings.

If one does not destroy the Dharma realm, then there is nothing to destroy, and thus nothing to approach, nor is one apart from the Dharma or in conflict with it. Not seeing afflictions, nor harboring grudges, this is the bodhisattva's first practice of diligence, not elevating or demeaning any Dharma while cultivating diligence.
If, Brahma Heaven!
There are no bodily causes and conditions, no verbal causes and conditions, and no mental causes and conditions, this is the first practice of diligence.

He replied:
The mind of the past has ceased, the future has not yet arrived, and the present does not abide. That which is extinguished does not arise again.

If one attains it, there is no thought of arising. Thus, one who abides always abides in non-abiding. As for the Dharma, if the correct Dharma arises equally, then there is no arising. Ultimate equality, correct balance, and emptiness are what constitutes diligence.
In this way, bodhisattvas will quickly attain the prediction and will attain the acceptance of the Dharma and perfect all practices.
The Buddha said to Brahma Heaven:
If bodhisattvas do not cultivate any dharmas, that is called giving;
Not protecting any dharmas is called upholding precepts;
If one does not contemplate any dharmas, that is called patience;
Not relying on any dharmas is called diligence;
Equally regarding all dharmas is called concentration;
Not conceptualizing any dharmas is called wisdom;
This is called neither increasing nor decreasing, neither creating nor not creating.

Always practicing giving without any expectation, upholding precepts while being equal in appearance, cultivating patience with inner and outer purity, practicing diligence to perfect accomplishment, being single-minded in meditation without any attachment, and revering wisdom without any conceptualization.

In this way, the one who fully practices patience, the bodhisattva practices widely and manifests various practices without attachment. Without attachment, they are equal to worldly dharmas, not delighting in gain or being displeased with loss, not rejoicing in praise or being dejected by slander, encountering pleasure or suffering.

If one encounters this immovable and unshakable, without increase or decrease, without joy or sorrow, having transcended all worldly dharmas, without suffering or distress, without agitation or trembling, without thought or non-thought, then there are no two things, free from all causes and conditions, heading towards the non-dual Dharma. For those who fall into the two views, arouse great compassion, and give rise to one's own mind to transform sentient beings, this is the first effort of Brahma Heaven, because it attains the forbearance of non-self, and then enters the great compassion for the multitude, and in the place of birth, embraces and rescues.
When the Buddha spoke of this effort, eight thousand bodhisattvas attained the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas.
